awd_titl_txt: RCN: Improving reconstructions of Cenozoic pCO2 and temperature change
awd_abstract_narration:
The contribution of atmospheric carbon dioxide (pCO2) to Earth's greenhouse effect has been known for more than a century, yet the detailed impacts of higher atmospheric CO2 concentrations on climate, terrestrial, and marine ecosystems are still subject to uncertainty. Earth history can aide scientists in improving their understanding of the interaction between pCO2 and global climate change, by providing records of past variations in pCO2 and climate recorded in the chemical composition of fossil shells and molecules. In the geologic past, Earth experienced profound changes in pCO2 and climate, but reconstructions remain challenging. This is due to the fact that many of the fossil-producing organisms are now extinct, landscapes have changed, and the chemical composition of the oceans and atmosphere have changed. While researchers actively explore individual archives and model sensitivities, less effort has been spent on developing a broader view of relative strengths and weaknesses of different approaches. This research coordination network will bring the paleoclimate/palcoeanographic research community together with the goal of openly recognizing uncertainties, constructively and jointly working to reduce them, and advancing the understanding of past and future climate change. 

To achieve this goal, two workshops will be held, which will bring together established and future specialists in reconstructing and modeling paleo-pCO2 from terrestrial and marine archives. The workshops will focus on validation opportunities for pCO2 proxies and carbon cycle models over the last 65 million years of earth history. Particular attention will be paid to proxy and model cross-calibrations and sensitivity studies in select time periods. A paleo-pCO2 database will be established, and position papers on best practices guidelines will be published. Opportunities will be discussed for carbon cycle and biogeochemical models to improve data syntheses and identify regions for desirable data additions. To improve capacity building within the US, up to four US scientists per year will be provided with an opportunity to enter an analytical and model training program, where they will learn new techniques from experts in the field. To ascertain that all research aspects and demographics are appropriately covered, a 16-member steering committee will both nominate expert workshop participants but also select promising but less well established candidates from an (inter-)national applicant pool.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual merit: This Research Coordination Network (RCN) brought together a group of terrestrial and marine paleoclimatologists, who discussed over the course of three workshops what is and is not known about geologic levels of atmospheric carbon dioxide and this gas' relationship to climate. This group includes experts of terrestrial and marine geologic archives for reconstructing paleo-CO2, and they focused their discussions on the Cenozoic era, i.e. the past 65 million years of Earth history. Over the past million years, ancient air trapped in polar ice can be extracted from ice cores and these enclosed bubbled provide a direct archive of ancient air and its gas composition. However, ice flows and records older than ~1 million years are currently not available and may never be recoverable. Because of this, paleoclimatologists use "proxies", i.e. surrogate data from ancient fossils and minerals that are closely related to atmospheric CO2 and allow estimates of paleo-CO2 from the time the organisms were alive and minerals were precipitated. This allows them to glean insight into the ancient atmosphere millions of years back in time.

Paleo-CO2 data published to date are manifold, but some of those data are decades old and because scientists' proxy understanding has evolved over time, the proxy experts consider some of the older records no longer scientifically sound. To help evaluate the different paleo-CO2 estimates published to date, this RCN designed a database that lists all paleo-CO2 records with their raw data and auxiliary information to translate proxy data into paleo-CO2 estimates. This database now allows scientists to review the sophistication of methods applied for each study and gauge how reliable those data are in the light of modern proxy understanding. At the last of the three workshops the experts vetted these data, quarantined some that are no longer considered reliable, and recalculated others for which newer calibrations and methods are available. These vetted data will form the basis for future studies of the relationship between past greenhouse gas concentrations and climate, and will guide scientists and funding agencies to where new work is most needed. A manuscript documenting the database and vetting process is currently being written by members of the RCN and the many participants of the three paleo-CO2 workshops. The products of this RCN inspired a range of follow-up studies that will be explored by smaller groups of proxy experts.

Broader impacts: This project also led to the development of a website that allows scientists and the general public to inform themselves about published paleo-CO2 data and the proxies used for generating them. The website can be viewed and explored at https://paleo-co2.org. In addition to plots of all paleo-CO2 data published to date, the website also features a suite of FAQs about the linkage between CO2 and climate, about paleo-proxies and how they can be deployed for reconstructing paleo-CO2. Further improvements to the website are released periodically; currently planned additions include explanatory videos for scientists and the general public, a map documenting the origin of the samples used for the paleoreconstructions, and an easier path for scientists to contribute their newest data to the database. 

Finally, the RCN also included an analytical and model training program for graduate students and postdocs. The program was broadly advertised on a number of US list serves, candidates applied and eight awardees were selected by the steering committee of the RCN. These awardees received funds to visit paleo-CO2 proxy experts at their respective institutions. All awardees submitted accomplishment reports and they will acknowledge this NSF funding in any manuscripts they write based on their training experience.
